comments.commentBody: The people in the education business can talk, talk, talk, but that will not change what they are doing: making money.  It is not rocket science to see through their double talk.  America is no different from any other Third World country.  It will do whatever is necessary to make money.  The American Century has ended.  Get over it.

micko: Lots of ways to make that grilled corn yummy. First off, be sure to soak it (husks on) in cold water for 10 to 15 minutes before grilling. You can remove the silks either before or after grilling. If before, be sure to fold the husks back into position.

When it's done (about 12 to 15 minutes), just peel back the husks and use the stem as a "handle." If butter, salt, and pepper aren't enough flavor, you can try other good flavors: lime/cilantro butter; garlic butter, then a squeeze of lime juice and a sprinkle of a mild cheese; butter mixed with honey and ancho chile powder.

There is no evidence in Exodus 16:15ff. that angels have anything to do with the miracle of manna. One minute, it isn’t there, and the next, it is: “And when the dew that day was gone up, behold, upon the face of the wilderness there lay a small round thing, as small as the hoar frost on the ground.” It may have fallen from the sky, or it may have just oozed up out of the earth. For that matter, neither the ancient Hebrews nor we modern readers even know what it is. King James erroneously makes a name out of an interrogative: “And when the children of Israel saw it, they said one to another, ‘It is manna’: for they wist not what it was.” St. Jerome: Quod cum vidisset filii Israel, dixerunt ad invicem: Manhu? quid significat: Quid est hoc? ignorabant enim quid esset. (“When the sons of Israel saw it, they said to one another, ‘Manhu?’ which means, ‘what is this?’, for they knew not what it was.”). Martin Luther translates this passage exactly the same way. In any case, miracles do not require the agency of angels.

Dr W (@24),

Just in case you missed it, the ELNINO clue incorporates wordplay (as signaled by the question mark). "Current event" is mildly misdirecting. In any case, since an El Nino event does affect oceanic currents the clue is accurate as well.

If you didn't miss the wordplay and just passed on an interesting link, thanks.

I'm here! Checking in while the Football Crazies (oops, I mean Buddies) watch two games at once; much calling out and the occasion scream of agony coming from that direction. Beautiful day here--and of course such fun.

@WHH
This is Kurt's third puzzle; how could you doubt me? Of course I've commented not only on his nice photo but also on his natty attire. However, he has now got on my bad side and needs to make amends. I could always decide to maul this little effigy in its 'naticky' attire.....

@pjbraxton
Congratulations--you are one serious PuzzleMan! (I was recently in the Arkansas tournament--see my blog for the suspenseful story....) I must say, however, that Will Shortz contributed one (1) puzzle to our event. I realize that our entire state has fewer residents than the metro-Arlington area, but is this fair? One wonders if Will S. is one of those folk who think 'short people got no reason to live'.....and ditto states who are a bit short of population.

We will go home tomorrow--driving through miles and miles of harvested cotton fields--the gins have hundredz of bales lined up waiting to be processed--as well as fields of harvested sorghum and soybeans, and (newly planted) winter wheat. If you don't realize what you are seeing, it feels like a whole lotta nothin'. The pecan crops are all in (check the prices in your grocery store--ouch) and fields are being plowed and disked. Small agrarian states are short on glamour, but long on productivity, even in the face of floods and drought (all in one year.)

Cheaper than you think? Perhaps or perhaps not. The claim involves three pairs of trend lines, one for each type of institution. In the top line of each pair - the sticker price - the trend is up - fueled by a grasping hand and tempered by trustees and state boards of higher ed. The key to Scott-Clayton's analysis is the bottom line of each pair, which reflects the transaction price - what is actually paid. She notes a buckle in each bottom line such that the trend declines modestly after the 2007-2008 year. Since the transaction price declines, college is cheaper than you think!

But is it? The point of the bottom trend line in each pair is that after adjusting for parental income and assets, the price paid is adjusted downwards from the list to reflect what can be paid by the student and parents. But whether the price paid is actually "cheaper" in a world of price discrimination depends on whether your income and assets have changed (and is to be made by the one who pays not the professor). If they have not changed and the price declines, then education is cheaper. But if your income and assets also have declined, then college may not be cheaper, even with a reduced price. It could even be more expensive if a student and his parents have suffered a larger percentage decrease in income and assets than the tuition has declined -- and if the "calculators" are biased. The price paid alone does not say whether the education is cheaper - except trivially - without considering the incomes/assets of those paying.

Did anything happen following 2007-2008 that might suggest that applicants have suffered significant losses in income, stock values, home values, etc.? An economic meltdown and a recession? So without knowing more about the incomes and wealth of the applicants, college could be cheaper or more expensive or as expensive as it was before the recession. Professor Scott-Clayton has not enlightened us very much here.

Now we know why Alabama and LSU are known for defense.

Neither has a quarterback worth mention and the only air game they have is voiced in the hot air media frenzy following these terribly boring teams.

If the championship game is supposed to be between the two best teams in the nation, we will see a repeat of tonight's epic LSU-Alabama match in January. There is not another team close to either, and fans know it. But the BCS won't let that happen--nor the playoff system that fans clamor for. Pity.

Now that the versatility of that Massachusetts town name has been made clear, it reminds me of a really old joke. Q: What do cowboy hats and hemorrhoids have in common? A: Every Athol has one.

I like the fact, as I'm sure Alex T does, is that Joon isn't chintzy when he makes his wagers. Here's hoping he's there at the end of the Tournament of Champions in position to emerge triumphant?

I realize how much more social interaction and development I need to plan for my only child when I look back at my childhood with a younger brother and a free-flowing neighborhood of kids. It makes a huge difference for my son when we have playdates or houseguests, so we make sure to do that

i sometimes have to play big sister with my kid when i realize he has been coddled too much by adulta. For instance, not letting him always go first in a game and putting mynfoot down! There are some harsh things a siblimg will do that are lessons, that an adultnwomt do to a kid. Esp teaching what is acceptable socially. We just need to work harder ti be sure he gets this and that the teAching is appropriate.
